Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for IEEE ICCCN 2015 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this grant is to support US-based students to attend the 24th International Conference on Computer Communications and Networks (ICCCN 2015) in Las Vegas, Nevada between August 3 and 6, 2015. After a committee-based review, funds will be given as NSF awards to US-based student authors of the conference, who will present research papers in the main conference.

Participation in conferences such as IEEE ICCCN is an extremely important part of graduate students' research and career development, providing the opportunity for them to present their own work, attend panel and keynote speech sessions, interact with peers and more senior researchers, and expose themselves to cutting edge work in the field of computer communication and networks. The student travel support enables more participation of US-based graduate students, especially underrepresented minorities, to attend ICCCN 2015.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Student Travel Support for IEEE ICCCN 2015 Conference

NSF Award ID: 1550442

Report submission period: 07/13/2015 - 06/26/2015

Among fifteen submitted NSF student travel grant applications, ICCCN selected nine excellent applicants as NSF student travel grant award winners after a well-designed committee-based review process. These award recipients are Ph.D. students in Computer Science, Computer Engineering and Electronic Engineering programs from US-based universities, have excellent academic records and are presenting their research results as the first or second authors in ICCCN 2015. Two award recipients present two papers each. One female student who received NSF student travel grant award also participated in Networking Networking (N2) Women meeting, a special event in ICCCN 2015 which is supported by many ACM and IEEE technical committees, NSF and industry research labs.   

Participation in conferences such as IEEE ICCCN is an extremely important part of the graduate students' research and career development, providing the opportunity for them to present their own work, attend panel and keynote speech sessions, interact with peers and more senior researchers, and expose themselves to leading-edge work in the fields of networking and communications. This NSF student travel support enables more participation of the US-based graduate students who would otherwise be unable to attend ICCCN 2015.


Last Modified: 07/11/2016
Modified by: Kewei Sha
